text: 7 things to know about today, plus just how honest are we in Orlando? Aug 26, 2015, 7:15am EDT Industries & Tags Cindy Barth Editor Orlando Business Journal Home of the Day THINKSTOCK For the fifth year in a row, the honesty rate in America has exceeded 90 percent,… more For the fifth year in a row, the honesty rate in America has exceeded 90 percent, according to the results of the 2015 National Honesty Index, a coast-to-coast social experiment conducted by Honest Tea. The index tests the honesty of Americans by setting up unmanned racks of Honest Tea beverages offered for $1 on the honor system. From July 17- Aug. 10, Honest Tea monitored thousands of interactions at 27 different locations across the country to see how honest people are when no one appears to be looking. The results found 94 percent of Americans were honest, down slightly from 95 percent in 2014. Overall, Atlanta was the most honest city in the United States at 100 percent, followed by Indianapolis at 99 percent honest. Providence, Tampa and Boston were found to be the least honest cities during this year’s experiment. As for Orlando, we came in with a 94 percent honesty rating. Here's some other interesting data from Honest Tea: Providence, R.I., remained at the bottom of the list for a second year in a row. One person in Providence paid for his beverage with a fake $1 million bill. For the first time in the history of the experiment, in the nation’s capital someone stole money from the collection box. In Orlando, a little girl purchased a beverage for a police officer, and then took a picture with him in front of the honesty store. Women proved to be more honest than men edging them out 95 percent to 93 percent honest. Brown hair came out as the most honest hair color with 96 percent. Last year’s most honest, blondes, were a close second at 95 percent. Bald individuals were the least honest at 91 percent. The complete National Honesty Index results are available at www.NationalHonestyIndex.com . And be sure to check out these other Wednesday headlines: Volusia OKs sale of Daytona Lagoon to United Parks Under a lease approved on Aug. 20 by the Volusia County Council, a subsidiary of United Parks will become the new owner and operator of Daytona Lagoon , a water park in Daytona Beach. United Parks has committed to investing more than $2 million in improvements at Daytona Lagoon over the next two years, with upgrades to include an overall facelift, a new attraction, a broader food selection and improved amenities for park visitors. United Parks also operates Hydro Adventures in Poplar Bluff, Mo., and the historic Rye Playland in Westchester County, N.Y. United Parks bought the water park from DBWP LLC through its Daytona Lagoon LLC subsidiary. The acquisition is expected to close on Sept. 30. Car-share program ending Sept. 12 as new vendor is sought The car-share program in Orlando is evolving, as a new vendor is being selected in September as the current vendor transitions out of the program. In October 2013, the Florida Department of Transportation’s District 5 Commuter Assistance Program and the city of Orlando partnered with Hertz 24/7 to bring car-share to downtown Orlando. The first phase of the program included 12 vehicles that were available for hourly rentals, as opposed to the 24-hour rental periods available through traditional car rental services. In July, Hertz said it would end its car-sharing service effective Sept. 12. FDOT has advertised an RFP to select a vendor for Phase 2, and project managers expect that selection to take place by Sept. 14, with car-share services re-introduced later this fall. ... Speaking of cars and traffic The 2015 Urban Mobility Scorecard released today offers some interesting insights and data on traffic congestion and commute times. In fact, traffic across the nation is getting worse, the report shows. According to the scorecard, travel delays due to traffic congestion caused drivers across the U.S. to waste more than 3 billion gallons of fuel and kept travelers stuck in their cars for nearly 7 billion extra hours — 42 hours per rush-hour commuter. The total nationwide price tag: $160 billion, or $960 per commuter. In 2014, the average commuter in Orlando spent 46 hours stuck in traffic, costing them each $1,044 in lost time and fuel, according to the report. Click here for the report, which is considered one of the most accurate measures of traffic conditions. Smartphone sales are slowing more than expected Sales of smartphones are expected to slow down more than expected this year as growth in mature markets like China slow down, according to new data released Tuesday from Framingham-based market research firm International Data Corp. IDC said that smartphone shipments are expected to grow 10.4 percent in 2015 to 1.44 billion units — lower than IDC's previous smartphone forecast of 11.3 percent year-over-year growth in 2015. Read more here . Job growth soaring for American Airlines, Southwest Employment is up at American Airlines and Southwest Airlines , as both carriers outpaced their competitors in job growth, according to figures released Thursday. Fort Worth, Texas-based American (Nasdaq: AAL) employed 59,905 fill-time workers and 7,427 part-timers in the United States in June, for a total of 67,332, up 6.4 percent from a year ago. Dallas-based Southwest (NYSE: LUV) employment rose 4.9 percent to 46,808 full-timers and 1,674 part-timers, totaling 48,482 nationwide. Only Atlanta-based Delta Air Lines (NYSE: DAL) with 84,728 total U.S. employees, and Chicago-based United Airlines (NYSE: UAL) with 84,059, employed more. Read more here .
